publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Fair ones to you──who hearts command
And gently Slay──wth, Fan in hand
Your favourite Punch A supplyant falls
And humbly for assistance calls
He humbly calls──and begs youd Stop
The Gothick rage of Vander Hop
Wh invades wth,out pretence──or Right
Or any law, but that of might
Our Pigmy Land──and treats our Kings
Like paltry──idle, wooden things
Has beat our Dancers──out of Doors
And calld our chastest Virgins──whores
He has not left our Queen, A rag on──
Has forcd away Our George, and Dragon
And broke our Wires──nay was not civil
To Doctor Faustus──and ye Devil
E'en me──he hurryd wth fell rage
Most hoarsely squealing off ye stage
And faith our fright, was very great
To see A Minister of State
Armd wth, Pow'r──and fury come
To force us from our little home
We feard──as I am sure we'd reason
An Accusation of high Treason
Till starting up, crys Bandimeer
Treason my freinds we need not fear
For gainst ye Brass──we us'd no power
Nor strove to save ye Chancellor.
Nor did we shew ye least Affection
To Rochfort on ye Meath Election──
Nor did we sing McHugh──what means
The villain──Ile dash out his brains
Tis no affair of State that brings
Me here──nor business of the Kings
Im come to seize you all as debtors
And bind you fast in Iron fetters
From sight of Ev'ry freind in town
Till fifty Pound be paid me downFifty quoth I──A Devilish Sum
But stay till ye new half pence come
Then we shall all be rich──as Jews
From Castle, down to lowest Stews
That sum──shall then, to you be told
Tho now, we can not furnish goldQuoth he──thou lovest Punch to prate
And coud for Ever hold debate
But thinkst thou──I have naught to do
But to stand arguing here with you,
Or thinkst thou──I'm from England come
To carry naught──but farthings home
Thou fool──I ne'er do things by halves
Farthings──were made for Irish Slaves
No Brass for me──it must be Gold
Or fifty Pound──in Silver told
That can by any means obtain
Pardon for thee──or for thy trainOh, votres humble Serviteur
I'm not in jest said I──Im Sure
But from ye bottom of my Belly
In sober sadness──I must tell you
I think it Special reasoning
That we fictitious men shoud bring
Brass Counters──made by Willm, Wood
Wch, may as well be understood
Right Ster──as we──flesh and blood
Then since we are but Mimick men
Pray──let us pay in Mimick Coin
Besides tis said──that you──and I
Are of ye selfsame family
And troth──I'm apt to think so too
For who is liker me──than you
Just the same grave, and awkard Grace
Show's it self forth──in Either face
And Each of us wth. labour strutts
Behind A flasket full of Gutts
We tally well, in these respects
But best of all──in intellects
For when you took ye Difference learnd
'Twixt ye word sorry──and concernd
And when upon ye grave affair
Amazd you gap'd behind ye Chair
They cryd──Lord how like Punchinello,
Is yt same fatt Beef witted fellow
Then prithee Cousin──let us Bus
And cease, to rack thy kindred thus────Quoth he thou vile Mistaken Beast
Sirrah──am I become thy jest
Now not A Puppet of you all
Shall stir A foot wth,in this Wall
Nor Merry Andrew beat the Drum
Till I am paid ye aforesaid Sum
Then marching off wth solemn pace
To write dispatches for his Grace
The Revel-master left the room
And us condemnd to fatal doomNow──fair One's──if I e'er found grace
Or if my Jokes──did ever please
Use all yr Interest wth ye Sec──
They say he's att the Ladys Beck
What tho he thirsts as much for gold
As ever Midas did of old
Your Charms──Im sure, can never fail
Your Eyes, must influence──must prevail
At your Command──he'll set us free
Let us──to you owe Liberty
Get us A licence now to play
And we in Duty bound shall prayY08B303B
